blocks.text: The three cases considered suggest a general rule, but it would be unwise to accept this as the true rule without the more rigid proof, which can be given.
We note that in all these cases the results take the form—

blocks.description: An application of the power rule.

blocks.text: Expand (x + h)^n using the Binomial Theorem (see p. 463, Part I). Then—

blocks.description: Expansion of (x + h) using the Binomial Theorem.

blocks.text: If h is increased to h + y, it takes a new value y + 8h, and from that—

blocks.description: Result from subtracting the two expansions.

blocks.text: containing products of (8^n) and higher powers of h.
Let h be continually decreased, and then, since h is a factor of each term, all and succeeding terms in the relation can be made as small as we please by sufficiently diminishing h.
